bibl.title: Report: A Memorial Project - The Preservation of Camp Lazear, by Philip Showalter Hench, November 21, 1946

div1.p: Hench reports to the Reed Memorial Association board on the Finlay-Reed controversy and the ongoing attempt to memorialize Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Report: A Memorial Project - The Preservation of Camp Lazear, by Philip Showalter Hench, November 21, 1946

p.hi: A Memorial Project: The Preservation of Camp Lazear

div1.p:
Report to the Walter Reed Memorial Association by Dr. P. S. Hench
Nov 21, 1946
(Semi-Confidential)

I have been honored indeed by my election to this Board. I know that
General Kean proposed my name because he has been aware of my deep
interest in the work of Dr Reed and his colleagues. One of the
by-products of my studies has been the rediscovery of Camp Lazear
and the remains of Reed's historic “Building number one” in which
were performed the crucial experiments on the propagation of yellow
fever. General Kean, the President of this Board, has permitted
me to outline to you a project for the preservation of Camp Lazear.
This project has for me much greater significance than the mere
further honoring of Reed, Lazear and their associates. To
explain the wider merits of the project necessitates a little
back-ground information.

p.hi: The Cuban-American Controversy: Finlay versus Reed

div1.p:
You recall, of course, that Dr Carlos Finlay of Havana originated the
mosquito theory of yellow fever in 1881, pursuing his investigations for 19
years during which time he inoculated 103 unquarrantined persons of whom 16
critical
subsequently developed what critical investigators considered then,
and still
consider, to have been spontaneous, not experimental yellow fever.
Then in 1900 the American Board of Officers discovered the cause
of the disease, proving the correctness of Finlay's theory. The Boards'
preliminary work up to the time of Lazear's death was done from
the Post Hospital, Camp Columbia, outside of Havana. Thereafter their the
main work part of the work was done at Camp Lazear, an isolated
experimental camp established on a nearby but secluded farm.

The reports of Reed et al aroused two strong conflicting
emotions in the mind of Finlay, 1) elation that his theory was
proven, 2) depression and mild antagonism that his work (i e his
“successful inoculations”) was rejected & his cases considered
to have been of spontaneous, not experimental disease. Finlay began
to defend the validity of his work and to his defense there
came certain prominent Cuban physicians, previously disbelieving
but now fired with the zeal to “vindicate Finlay.” At first
this controversy was kept by Reed on a dispassionate scientific
plane but after Reed's death two years later, the argument became
somewhat bitter. Doctor Finlay's son (whom I visited twice) told me
CL
At this time I wish merely to acquaint you with my present plans
for the project and to ask, not for your financial support
only but for your moral supportapproval & advice.

“their side” of the controversy. Later in a letter to me (1942) Dr Finlay's son,
himself also a physician, wrote me “There is no question that among
the U. S. A. elements at first and later U. S army U S A (meaning
U S Army) elements at first and later by elements of the
Rockefeller Foundation there was for many years a marked
tendency to ignore and belittle my father's experimental
work.” This view is widely held thruout Cuba & was repeatedly expressed to me
by Cuban physicians, sometimes with some heat and asperity. In this view Finlay's son is unfortunately partly correct.
Certain American reports (not those of Reed) did pass by Finlay's theory
rather ungenerously and one or two of Carroll's later papers were
were properly possibly unnecessarily curt and offensive to the
Finlay and friends. Later reporting some of the early reports of the
Rockefeller Foundation served to add to the misunderstanding.

As a reaction to this “neglect” of Finlay there arose and
still exists in Cuban professional our and governmental
circles a rather rabid pro-Finlay school headed for years by
Dr Dominguez who, to “Vindicate Finlay,” wrote a book
strongly pro-Finlay and anti-Reed (or anti-U. S) concluding
that the Americans merely confirmed. Finlay's proven work.
This book published in French in 1935 and translated into
English in 1938, received sufficient recognition that its
author was decorated by the French government.
Cuban Honors for Finlay: Cuban neglect ofattitude toward Reed

A corollary of the Cubans' desire to honor Finlay has been
their neglect of Reed, a neglect which at times has been so obvious as to make one realize it was intended. Examples: (1) In the Courtyard of the Cuban Dept of Public Health was erected a magnificent statue to Finlay; on its pedestal is inscribed
the reasons for the honor; no mention Reed & colleagues are
unmentioned. (2) In the
park in front of this building is another statue of Finlay, flanked by
are four busts-of of Finlay, Delgado, Guiteras, Gorgas, and Lazear;
none of Reed; no mention of him or of Agramonte. (3) Agramonte
became looked upon as something of a “traitor” to
Finlay & the Cuban viewpoint because he, tho a Cuban,
defended the American Board's views. 4) I have read
numerous articles by Cuban physicians extolling Finlay to
the almost total neglect of the Americans. In other words
the Cubans have vigorously participated in the very tactics
they deplored in others.

p.hi: The Compromising Elements in Cuban Medical Circles

div1.p:
All along there have beencertain Cuban physicians have refused to join
in the controversy and have insisted on giving due credit to both sides.
ALBERTINI
Doctor Albertini, one of Cuba's most prominent physicians and Doctor Domingo
Ramos, the physician who was first Minister of War, 'later Minister of
Health under Batista notably fostered amicability. Results:
(1) The government named the army's chief hospital the Agramonte
General Hospital. (2) They erected purchased what they (erroneously) thought
was the site of Camp Lazear (right across the railroad track from the main Cuban army post and its hospital), put up a little memorial fence
and sign (mentioning the American Board members) and planned
someday to erect a memorial hospital. 3) In the Las Animas
Hospital where Lazear was supposedly incurred his accidental
fatal mosquito-bite they put up a wooden & cardboard memorial plaque to Lazear: put up “temporarily” about 1928
to be replaced by a bronze one, the temporary one was still up
in 1940. 4) Dr Ramos in 1939 published a paper
proposing a national (medical) memorial to the “yellow
Fever heroes” (Americans included);not yet erected.
5) In 1944 a mural was done in a government hospital-
it included Lazear.

Drs Albertini & Ramos have told me they considered the
anti-U S, anti-Reed, rabid pro-Finlay controversy most
unfortunate & undignified & hoped it would die out as its
more zealous participants passed away. But despite the
grudging inclusion of the Americans in recent honors the Cuban government and
medical profession are doing little
about concrete memorials; it is mostly talk.They continue
to almost deify Finlay. He is the Cuban Pasteur, growing in
fame,partly because he is a martyr, an injured , misunderstood &
neglected genius (neglected by the Cuban (incidentally neglected mostly by the
Cubans themselves for 19 years) and because he is their one great scientist.
Evidences: 1) The Finlay postage stamp. (2) Cancellation
marks - “To the glory of Finlay and Science” - used in
recent years to cancel postage stamps, (3) Erection of the
Finlay Institute (a sort of governmental Rockefeller Foundation,
4) “The Order of Finlay” is Cuba's highest Scientific honor and (governmental) honor & decoration.
(4
5) The annual Finlay birthday celebrations and orations. Many of the latter
orations are so intemperate in their “vindication of Finlay” that they
almost smack of “hate sessions.”

p.hi: The Discovery of the Lost Camp Lazear

div1.p:
Reed's official reports did not exactly identify the location of Camp Lazear.
As stated the Cuban government finally sought for it and bought what was
supposed to be it. In 1940 on on a vacation to Havana I sought to find the
real site; with the help of Mr. John Moran (one of Reed's first guinea-pigs)
and Mr. Pogolotti, a Cuban real estate man, this was accomplished.
We reported this to Cuban authorities who at first expressed
disbelief, annoyance, & resentment. I was asked to present to the
Cuban government a documented report which I did in 1941.
Since then my report has obviously been accepted (through I was most
)because 1) the memorial sign & fence at the false
camp site were allowed to fall down & were hauled away 2) the
Lions'and Club of Havana has just placed a memorial plaque
on a stone fence near the true camp. 3) Dr Ramos sent me a
letter expressing “the gratitude and appreciation of the Government of Cuba,” etc., etc.
(I have available all the necessary maps, photographs & other
identifying evidence). propound thats "of the Cuban Government to the

Memorializing Camp Lazear as a Cuban-American Memorial, and preserving the historical little
“Building Number One” would serve several purposes:
1) Contribute to medical historical accuracy.
2) Foster Cuban-American cultural & professional
relationships
3) Perhaps initiate a new era of professional friendship & stop the acrimonious
debate by making an occasion for a “love feast” to
bury the hatchet
4) Please and placate the Finlay family. (I discussed
this idea with Dr Finlay; he was much pleased & told me he
would contribute some of his father's historical mementoes.)

Incidentally Camp Lazear is uniquely suitable as a site for a Cuban - American memorial because
investigation shows that on that very same farm Dr Finlay
years before had carried out 2 or 3 of his early inoculations-
- a fact and known only to very few but discussed with
much pleauresatisfaction by Doctor Finlay's son and me. (We have absolute
proof of this.)

Unfortunately the site of Camp Lazear is in an undistinguished & very humble
part of Quemados de Marianao (suburb of Havana), but it is just about 3 blocks off
the main highway street, The Calzada Real. My original idea included the
following: 1) Purchase the Camp site: the site would comprise about
one small town-block but a half-block would be sufficient if funds for the
whole site were not available. The site is fortunately still empty; it
is used as a corn field but workers' small 3 or 4 room houses
surround it on 2 sides. 2) Enclose the the remains of “Building 1”
in a modest museum. 3) Restore Repair Building 1 (it is only
14 x 20 feet) and restore its interior as it was during the experiments
(a stoveSTOVE, 3 cots, a couple trunks of blood-stained bedding)
4) Place a small stone pile (memorial) on the site of “Building 2,”
80 yards in front of Building 1. 5) Place a bronze plaque on
the stone wall (the main wall) of the Finca San Jose of which
Camp Lazear was a part. This wall still encloses the lovely
old main house of the finca finca & is on the main highway
(main street) 2-3 blocks from the Camp. This plaque would be
passed daily by the towns' main traffic and would indicate
the proximity of the Camp; a road already leads directly from
the main street to the Camp-site. 6) Collect and house in
the small museum building (enclosing to enclose
Building one) souvenirs, photographs, original charts, etc. pertaining
to all the Cuban & American “Conquerors of Yellow Fever”
(aspar (Finlay, Delgado, Reed, Lazear, Carroll, Agramonte,
Guiteras the American volunteers, Guiteras). (I have
already collected a mass of such data from the families of
Reed & Lazear, et al from Dr Howard Kelly, Generals Kean & Truby, & others; should it seem more “fair” to share
this data historical data with an American medical museum
it could be copied and each museum get half of the original).
(7) Erect a little stone pile (bronze plaque) on the site of the false Camp Lazear; actually this was where the patients with experimental
yellow fever were moved to (from Camp Lazear) and cared for & where Lazear died,
(just across a railroad track from the main hospital of the Cuban army).

The Rojas family which still owns the main part of the Finca San
Jose were delighted to discover the historical facts of their old homestead.
Madam Rojas is quite wealthy & will cooperate fully; her children
were equally pleased.

That part of the Rojas farm (Finca San Jose) with where was Camp
Lazear actually the the Camp had been, was sold to Senor Macia, a wealthy
(6
Cuban business man who uses the adjacent quarry and rents
the Camp Lazear site as a corn field. He was most interested,
promised full cooperation, said he would probably either give
me the site or sell it at a nominal cost when the time came provided
it be used as a memorial site. In 1941 he gave me (as a sign of
his good faith) a deed to the little building (but not the land) but
it was only good for 2 years (the war completely interrupted my plans).

Certain governmental personalities promised full cooperation.
Dr Ramos and other Cuban medical authorities visited the camp
with me; there was some talk of moving Building one to the
site of the false site “because that is where Lazear died and is so
convenient to the Army Hospital - a couple hundred yards
away.” I was introduced taken to President Batista who in a
very short (but polite) 5 minute interview expressed his sincere (?)
interest & said he hoped he could be present at the dedication
& make it a governmental ceremony.

Under the supervision of Mr. Moran I spent about $5000 to repair the leaky roof of Bldg one
and a small additional sum for incidentals. (It is still
inhabited by a tenant).

Batista and Ramos are out. The new President,Dr. Grau San Martin, is a physician
and could be readily interested in the project so I am told. Certain elements
have interested themselves but want to make it a Cuban (not a
Cuban-American) medical memorial. Mr. Macia, owner of the Camp site,
offered by letter to sell me the site for a nominal nominal sum-$15000.
I promptly sent him a check which he returned with a
vague letter: I think he wants to do nothing until he
knows that the plan will go through. I don't blame him
& I am sure he will sell the property without too much
trouble although his ideas as to “the appropriate price” may be undergoing
since though revision.

Doctor Hart, one of the chief officials of Winthrop Chemical
Company which has large sales in Cuba became interested in
my story, visited Havana, took photos of the Camp site
& published a story in Spanish which attracted some attention
(7
Thereafter I understand a radio station publicized the story of the
discovery of Camp Lazear and I believe there was a Sunday newspaper article thereon. (I didn't see it).

Doctor Presno, Minister of Public Health and Sanitation became
(temporarily) with interested and promised to Mr. Moran certain things (help
in protecting and repairing Building #1) but nothing has
come of it so far. A couple Cuban physicians, having heard of all this,
wrote me, promising enthusiastic support when needed; they
this was spontaneous on their part as I've had no time
since 1942 to further materially the project.

Dr James Peabody A New York biologist who early became intensely
interested in the yellow fever story & was responsible for the early
pensions to the participants, became interested in our proposal project &
suggested raising funds “in memory of a college classmate who had
died of yellow fever.” I politely declined funds that might
necessitate memorializing the spot to one who had no
connection with the conquest of the disease.

del.unclear:
Dr Morris Fishbein and Dr Edgar Mazer with others
recently formed the “Finlay Institute of the Americas”; Dr
Mazer heard of my work, and visited me & had some vague
discussion about my forming forces with them (I think
there Institute is merely a paper - affair; I think they wanted
a project about which they could really). Dr Mazer
wrote & spoke of having me made a Director of there Institute. I made
no commitments. Nothing came of the all this. Several certain officers of the Institute later
vented Havana & were decorated with the Finlay medal
obviously perhaps their interest has in my perfect has dismissed.

div1.p:
It was suggested that the Department of Pan American Cultural Relationships
of the U S Government might sponsor our project and that I see Nelson
Rockefeller about it. Last year the Surgeon General arranged for me to meet him.
He allowed
me about 10 minutes, showed no interest and said their department
was about to be re-organized & would have no funds for such a
project. (Aren't they still sending movie stars on good will trips to South America?)

The only concrete thing has been done by the Lions' Club
of Havana which placed a plaque on the wall of the Finca
San Jose.

Still believing that the project has merit I now wish to gave more too
push it along. If others agree to its merits the first requirement and
an urgent one, into purchase the land & shack with shack &
new we would is to have Cuban (or American.) wood experts mates inspect the little shack &
advise us whether or how the wood can be preserved and/or restored. The the historical little shack is in pretty bad shape, even though it is still lived in.
Mr. Moran is quite pessimistic about it. However, I have had some
correspondence with the Dept of Agriculture in Washington; although my
correspondents have only seen photos of the harvest shack & not the
shack itself, they believe tentatively that it can be preserved. It isn't in much worse then condition than was the little house, Reed's birth place,
nicely restored a few years ago.

2) If so, the next step would be the purchase of the lot & shack
or to purchase the lot & could an exact replaced of teh thick.

3) Next we must at once build some sort of a temporary
protection around it - either a strong new wood on or
galvanized iron covering large examples to allow protect
it against the elements (it survived the tornado of 1926
which destroyed Bldg 2; miraculously it also survived the
severe tornado of 1944). This outside cover should be large
enough to permit workmen to begin the first stages of restoration,
chemical protection against termites, etc. If the shack cannot
be preserved an exact replica could be erected on the spot.

4) Then in greater leisure we could raise the funds necessary
for the memorial building and the small additional markers.
I have neither the inclination, energy or time to same work
“collect nickels.” I think the If the project is worthwhile
I think it could be underwritten by a few institutions.

In 1950 is the 50th Anniversary of the “Conquest of Yellow
Fever” a most appropriate time to finish & dedicate the project.
My first ideas on the cost of the building were modest: to erect
a little museum building of simple Cuban style about
35 x 60 feet, perhaps larger. A Cuban architect in
1940 hazarded a gauss that it might cost $20,000 might would
be enough (1940 prices). If a few people individuals or
one or two institutions are to pay for it alone and
wish to present it to the Cuban government as a modest,
not an elaborate, memorial the cost need not be great.

In Before proceeding very far we should find out
whether the Cuban government would accept it as a
(9
“national monument” and support its care. It was my thought
that the building should be large enough to have the shack
in the center of the (main) room with a protecting cost rope
cordon (on standards) around it; with the front & 3 sides
left intact (restored as necessary) but with the back of the
little shack entirely open so that visitors passing around it
would see at the inside arranged as it originally was.

The remaining space would be given to displays: wall
displays, mostly, a few cabinets. In one corner would be
the care-taker's desk, with souvenir post perhaps with
souvenir postcards and a little illustrated booklet.

If enough funds could be raised one end of the building
could contain a small 4 room apartment for the care-taker
(small living room, bedroom, combined kitchen-dinette, bath).

It must be pre-determined whether the Cuban government
or the Cuban medical association would consent to be
responsible for the up keep & protection of the little museum.
Undoubtedly the Government would improve the road
and the of small grounds in front of it.
Mr. Moran, still living in Cuba, advises me not to bother any more with
procrastinating and changing Cuban politicians
but to get into
direct touch with President George San Martin of Cuba
which he assures me I can readily do; Mr. Moran also
believes that the strong support of the Cuban Havana Lions' Club
can be readily obtained. I intend to correspond with
these people in the immediate future but before doing so
would like to be a little more sure of what American
support I can expect so that I may not approach the
Cubans “empty-handed.” Mr. Moran has been
a most faithful and efficient “agent” for me in all
my Cuban dealings. I can count on him with completely
for continued guidance and help. In his opinion
“It is not at all unlikely that the Cuban government
would declare the site a national monument, at
the same time allowing you free rein to build the
memorial according to your own plans.”

If wether one the plans are kept modest perhaps $25,000-$30,000 would be
sufficient; $20,000-$25,000 for the museum, $1,000 (nominal?) for the land
$1,500 for restoration of the shack
$2,500 for 2 small stone and concrete markers
with bronze tablets at the site of
Bldg 2 & at the “false camp-site”
where Lazear died & the others were
cared for (one has already been placed
on the wall of the Finca San Jose).

I did not have in mind a pretentious memorial. But if
the American or the Cuban Government or the Cuban medical profession could be
interested in a material way, the cost of a more elaborate
memorial might be shared. However, I deem it wise to
start modestly & expect little or no Cuban financial help.

I have been led to understand that if or when the memorial
is erected it will be made an official Cuban affair, with
over
the Cuban President on hand. It would of course be most
appropriate to have also representatives of the American Government
and of the Cuban & American medical professions and societies; also close relatives
of those memorialized. other interest The immediate relatives
of Dr Reed and Lazear know fully of this plan & are have been
most helpful & interested.
Colonel Siler

What I now say is entirely unofficial but I have been led to believe that
the Mayo Clinic & Foundation with may contribute materially; the matter will be
presented officially to them very soon. (Insert from below) (The Mayo Foundation has certain Spanish-American ties: quite a few Cuban
& Latin American patients come to the clinic; we have certain Fellows
from those countries; Doctor Charles Mayo also received the Finlay medal and
other Cuban honors some years ago.)

I do hope that the Rockefeller Foundation (or a member of the Rockefeller
family) may join the Mayo Foundation in this enterprise. No doubt This would be particu-
larly appropriate because of the long interest of the
Rockefeller this Foundation in the yellow fever researches. I have no entre' to
the Foundation but have met Dr Sawyer, the former Director and
could contact him.

Reed is still will always be a hero to the U S. Public
Health association; perhaps their help could be obtained.

The va alumni associations of the various American medical
schools and hospitals related to Finlay, Reed, Carroll, Lazear, and
Agramonte might help; they all graduated from American medical schools.

The Rojas family is wealthy & might desire to contribute
something to the memorialization of their own homestead.

If it could be done in a proper manner certain
pharmaceutical houses with Spanish-American interests
might contribute.

Only $1,00000 contributed by Mrs. Hench, as a “little starter”; deposited in a
“Camp Lazear Memorial Fund.”

Conclusion: I would be grateful for whatever suggestions and
advice the search of the Walter Reed Board members
of the Walter Reed Memorial Association may give me.
I hope that the project I believe that the project
outlined is in harmony with the spirit & purposes
of this association.

Respectfully submitted,
Philip S. Hench, M. D.
Mayo Clinic
